StringWithMarkup.String: Of the 671 stations reporting heptachlor in industrial effluents in EPA's STORET database, 3.0% contained detectable levels of this chemical with a median concn of <0.007 ug/l(1). Heptachlor residues were detected in treated wastewater effluents from coal mining, foundry, and nonferrous manufacturing industries at a mean concns of 2.2 ug/l (4.3% of 47 samples), 8.7 ug/l (range, 5 to 31 ug/l; 11 samples), and 0.1 ug/l (range, not detected to 0.7 ug/l; 55 samples), respectively(2). Heptachlor was detected in leachate from the Love Canal hazardous waste site at concns less than 10 ug/l(3). Findings from the Nationwide Urban Runoff Program priority pollutant samples collected in 1982 showed that heptachlor was detected at a concn of 0.1 ppb in 5% of urban runoff samples from 15 cites(4). In New York City from 1989 to 1993, heptachlor was detected in municipal water treatment facilities influent and effluent at concns ranging from 0.021 to 0.35 ug/l and 0.02 to 0.447 ug/l, respectively(5).

StringWithMarkup.String: SOIL: Applications of 1 to 1.6 lbs/acre heptachlor to soil left no residues 15 months later; application of 2 lbs/acre left 0.26 to 0.47 ppm heptachlor and heptachlor epoxide 1 yr later; application of 3 lb/acre left 0.21 to 0.40 ppm heptachlor 4 months later and 0.18 to 0.32 ppm 1 year later; application of 6 lb/acre left 0.49 to 3.61 ppm 4 months later and 0.63 to 2.24 ppm 1 yr later(1). Loam soil, treated 5 years with heptachlor at a rate of 5 lbs/acre per yr, contained 4.6% of applied heptachlor 5 years after cessation of treatment; thus the mean residue level in soil was 0.70 ppm heptachlor and heptachlor epoxide(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: SOIL: In 1969, heptachlor was detected in soil of Bakersfield CA, Houston TX, Manhattan KS, Miami FL, Milwaukee WI, Salt Lake UT, and Waterbury CT at avg concns of <0.01 ppm (range, 0.02 to 0.10 ppm; freq, 4% of samples), <0.01 ppm (range, 0.01 to 0.02 ppm; freq, 6% of samples), <0.01 ppm (range, 0.02 to 0.09 ppm; freq, 10% of samples), <0.01 ppm (range, 0.01 to 0.20 ppm; freq, 6% of samples), 0.02 ppm (range, 0.02 to 0.45 ppm; freq, 12% of samples), 0.01 ppm (range, 0.01 to 0.24 ppm; freq, 12% of samples), and 0.01 ppm (range, 0.01 to 0.53 ppm; freq, 8% of samples), respectively(1). Heptachlor concns ranged from not detected to 0.40 ppm in soil samples collected in 1964, 1966, and 1969 from 16 farms in southwestern Ontario(2). Agricultural soils on the North Coast Region of New South Wales, Australia were shown to contain heptachlor at concns ranging from undetected levels to 0.06 ppm(3). Data from the 1971 National Soils Monitoring Program at 1,486 sampling sites in 37 states showed heptachlor was detected in 4.9% of the samples from cropland soils at concns ranging from 10 to 1,370 ppb(4). A survey was made of 36 Alabama agricultural soils to assess residues of past use of heptachlor(5); the mean concn of heptachlor in this survey was 0.043 ug/kg dry wt (range, <0.02 to 0.121 ug/kg dry wt)(5). The mean concn of heptachlor in contaminated soil at agrichemical facilities (in Illinois) was 50 ug/kg (range, 1.4 to 2,900)(6). Heptachlor was identified in soil extracts from a timber treatment facility near Auckland, New Zealand at a mean concn of 14 ug/kg (range, 0 to 233 ug/kg)(7).

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENTS: Of the 1665 stations reporting heptachlor in sediments in EPA's STORET database, 236.0% contained detectable levels of the chemical with a median concn of 0.1 ug/kg(1). From 1979 to 1981, heptachlor was detected in sediments from Niagara-on-the-Lake with an 8% frequency of occurrence and mean and median concns of 1 and <1 ng/g, respectively(2). Heptachlor concns in all sediment samples collected from the St. Lawrence River were less than 1 ug/kg(3). Heptachlor was detected in sediments from Manukau Harbor, New Zealand at concns of less than 0.1, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6 and 0.4 ng/g for sampling points located at Waiuku Inlet, Drury Creek, Pukaki Creek, Mangere Inlet and Big Muddy Creek, respectively(4). Heptachlor was detected in surface sediments of the Shatt al-Arab River (Iraq) and in surface sub-sediments of the Tigris River (Iraq) at mean concns of 24 ng/l (range, 13 to 48 ng/l; freq, 100% of samples) and 9 ng/l (range, 2 to 15 ng/l; freq, 100% of samples), respectively(5). The concn of heptachlor in sediment samples from River Nile (Cairo, Egypt) ranged from 89.5 to 112 mg/kg and 60.1 to 92.3 mg/kg in the winter and summer of 1991, respectively(6). The concn of heptachlor in sediment samples from Manzala Lake (Egypt) ranged from 72.6 to 90.3 mg/kg and 10.5 to 93.6 mg/kg in the winter and summer of 1991, respectively(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: Between 1985-1986, the ambient air concn in Bloomington, IN was 2.2 to 190 ng/cu m(1). Heptachlor was detected in the ambient air of Iowa City, IA and Orlando, FL and at avg concns of 19.2 ng/cu m and 2.3 ng/cu m, respectively(2). Heptachlor was also detected in the air of Stockholm, Sweden between October 13 to 15, 1983(3). Heptachlor was detected in the ambient air outside 5 of 9 homes in Jacksonville, FL at a mean concn of 0.025 ug/cu m (range, 0.009 to 0.059 ug/cu m)(4). StringWithMarkup.String: Commercially prepared baby food sampled from July 1963 to June 1967, the heptachlor epoxide residues were found in 0.9% of the 684 samples with most of the positive samples showing residues in the range from trace to 0.03 mg/kg. /Heptachlor epoxide/

Reference: Shivankar VJ, Kavadia VS; Indian J Plant Prot 18 (2): 167-76 (1990)

StringWithMarkup.String: Side-dressing of heptachlor (5% dust) resulted in the absorption of residues in root crops 35 days before harvest. Absorption of residues in potatoes were 9 to 11% of initial deposits of 3.72 to 3.85 ppm heptachlor; absorption of residues in sweet potatoes were 13 to 15% of initial deposits of 5.46 to 5.84 ppm heptachlor; absorption of residues in onions were 13 to 16% of initial deposits of 11.20 to 11.69 ppm heptachlor. The absorption was highest in potato followed by sweet potato and onion. The harvest time residues were considerably influenced by the post-harvest processings. Washing alone removed 22-29% residues from all the crops; washing followed by peeling and cooking reduced 85-93% residues from sweet potato, and 94-100% residues from potato. Dehydration reduced 74-100, 80-100 and 84-100% residues from sweet potato, potato and onion, respectively. Cooking was most effective, and left 0.03 ppm of heptachlor in sweet potato and potato, and no residues in onion at 10.0 kg active ingredient/hectacre.

Reference: (1) FDA; Total Diet Study-Summary of Residues Found Ordered by Pesticide Market Baskets Food and Drug Administration p. 33 (2000) 91-3991

StringWithMarkup.String: The mean concn of heptachlor was measured, as part of FDA Total Diet Study, in homemade cornbread (0.002 ppm), cracked wheat bread (0.0005 ppm), plain bagel (0.0006 ppm), toasted English muffin (0.0007 ppm), and cheese pizza (0.0004 ppm)(1).

Reference: (1) Duggan RE et al; Pestic Res Levels in Foods in US from July 1, 1969 to June 30, 1976 FDA and AOAC (1983)

StringWithMarkup.String: The concn of total heptachlor (ie, heptachlor and heptachlor epoxide) was measured in the following foods in the US(1): domestic cheese (avg, 0.0001 ppm; 0.4% of 784 samples); red meat(avg, 0.016 ppm; 20.7% of 15,200 samples); poultry (avg, 0.013 ppm; 16.5% of 11,340 samples); domestic whole grains (avg, <0.0001 ppm; 0.2% of 947 samples); domestic vine and ear vegetables (avg, <0.0001 ppm; 0.4% of 2,954 samples); imported vine and ear vegetables (avg, 0.0006 ppm; 0.2% of 4,117 samples); corn and corn products (avg, 0.126 ppm; range, trace-19.0 ppm; 3.6% of 280 samples); soybeans (avg, 0.04 ppm; range, 0.04-0.05 ppm; 1.9% of 104 samples). Heptachlor was infrequently found in leaf and stem vegetables(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: Heptachlor was detected in 1 of 11 and 3 of 10 cheese samples from Comarca Lagunera and Soconusco, Mexico(1). Over 50% of the chicken's eggs from Comarca Lagunera, Mexico also contained heptachlor(2). Heptachlor was detected in 16 of 105 chicken fat samples collected between Apr 1980 and Feb 1982 in Kenya; the mean concn was <0.01 mg/kg (range, 0.01 to 0.03 mg/kg)(3). Heptachlor and heptachlor epoxide combined were detected at avg concns of 5.3 ppb in 1974 and 6.6 ppb in 1980 upon soybeans grown in Illinois(4). For vegetables surveyed in the markets of Delhi, India from Aug 1984 to Jan 1986, the avg heptachlor concns were 12 ug/kg for potato; 4 ug/kg for colocasia; 20 ug/kg for radish; 15 ug/kg for onion; 4 ug/kg for cabbage; 2 ug/kg for cauliflower; 1 ug/kg for coriander; 21 ug/kg for spinach; 23 ug/kg for brinjal; 1 ug/kg for ladyfinger; 1 ug/kg for french beans; 4 ug/kg for tomato; 389 ug/kg for green peas; 23 ug/kg for bottle gourd; 2 ug/kg for smooth gourd; 2 ug/kg for bitter gourd; 10 ug/kg for cucumber; and 42 ug/kg for chilies(5). As part of the Belgian Total Diet Study (1991-1993), heptachlor was detected in raw tea at a mean concn of 0.002 ppm (max, 0.03 ppm; 1.6% of samples positive)(6,7).

StringWithMarkup.String: Different fish species from Abu Qir Bay, Idku Lake, and Maryut Lake in Alexandria, Egypt, were assayed for residues of organochlorine insecticides and polychlorinated biphenyls(1). The fish were obtained from commercial fishermen in 1985: Pagellus erythrinus, Sargus vulgarius, Siganus rivulatus, Sphyraena sphyraena, and Trigla hirundo from Abu Qir Bay; and Tilapia fish from Idku and Maryut Lakes(1). The waters from which the fish were obtained receive drainage from industrial, agricultural and urban activities. Water samples were not assayed for specific components(1). Heptachlor was detected in all fish in the study(1). The highest levels (5.3 ug/kg) were found in Pagellus erythrinus from Abu Qir Bay. Concns were highest in larger fish, but a linear increase with size was not apparent(1). Heptachlor was detected in common carp, channel catfish, smallmouth and largemouth bass, rock bass, pumpkinseed, bowfin, lake trout and northern pike from Lake Michigan collected at White Lake and the St Joseph, Kalamazoo, Grand, Muskegon, Pere Marquette, Manistee, Platte, Boardman, Grand Traverse, Manistique, Whitefish, Escanaba and Ford Rivers at concns ranging from 0.001 to 0.008 mg/kg wet weight(2).

StringWithMarkup.String: Heptachlor was detected at an avg concn of 0.0002 ppm (0.3% of 2,901 samples) in domestic fish(1). Heptachlor was detected at an avg concn <0.0001 ppm (0.4% of 361 samples) in imported fish(1). Heptachlor was detected in fish collected from Great Lake harbors and tributary mouths at the Astabula and Black Rivers, Ohio; Sheboygan, Memonimee, Kinnickinnic, Fox and Wolf Rivers, Wisconsin; and Chequamegon Bay, Lake Superior, Wisconsin at concn <0.002 mg/kg(2). Heptachlor was detected in Jack fish (Seriolella violacea) collected from the Chilean coast at an avg concn of 900 ppb(3). Shrimp (Penaeus setiferus and Penaeus aztecus) from Calcasieu River/Lake Complex, LA contained heptachlor at concns ranging from not detected to 0.75 ug/g(4). In 1984, heptachlor and heptachlor epoxide combined were detected in Cyprinid Fish (Barbus xanthopterus) from the Shatt al-Arab River, Iraq at concns ranging from Not detected to 13 ppb(5). In March to June, 1986, heptachlor was detected in Black Bullhead from the Garigliano River in Southern Italy at an avg concn of 10 ng/g (21% of samples)(6). Heptachlor was detected in Black Bullhead, Chub, Common Carp and Eel from the Volturno River in Southern Italy at avg concns of 20, 6, 5, and 5 ng/g (70% of samples)(6). Heptachlor was detected in Chub, Common Carp, Eel and Tench from the Calore River in Southern Italy all at avg concns of 5 ng/g (78% of samples)(6). Heptachlor was detected in Black Bullhead and Bleak from the Sele River in Southern Italy both at an avg concn of 5 ng/g (35% of samples)(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: Freshwater fish collected in 1984 for the National Contaminant Biomonitoring Program run by the US Fish and Wildlife Service contained a geometric mean residue concn of total heptachlor (heptachlor epoxide plus traces of heptachlor) of 0.01 ppm (wet wt)(1). Heptachlor residues in fish were present in fish in 49.1% of the collection stations (n=112) located at major rivers throughout the US, including Alaska and Hawaii(1). The concn of heptachlor in fish (eg, Karmout, Bolti and Shilan) samples from the River Nile (Cario, Egypt) and Manzala Lake (Egypt) were measured in the summer and winter of 1991(2). The concn of heptachlor in fish from Manzala Lake were 1.9 to 2.8 ug/kg fresh wt for Karmout in the winter 1991, and 3.4 to 3.6 ug/kg fresh wt for Karmout and 1.2 to 1.5 ug/kg fresh wt for Bolti in the summer of 1991(2). The concn of heptachlor in fish from the River Nile was 0.96 to 3.50 ug/kg fresh wt for Shilan, 3.25 ug/kg fresh wt for Karmout, and 2.63 ug/kg fresh wt for Bolti in the winter of 1991(2); the concn was 3.0 to 5.2 ug/kg fresh wt for Shilan in the summer of 1991(2). The mean concn of heptachlor residues in imported mackerel and sardine samples collected from Greater Cairo (Egypt) governorates were 0.275 ppm (range, not detected to 0.145 ppm; 36% of samples positive) and 0.0465 ppm (range, not detected to 0.218 ppm; 50% of samples positive), respectively(3). At Mar Meno Lagoon (SE Spain), the concn of heptachlor residues in the bivalves, Venerupis aurea and Cerastoderma glaucum, were 2.25 ug/kg and 2.00 ug/kg, respectively(4).

StringWithMarkup.String: Eggs and 5 day old chicks from the same clutch of Herring gull (Laru argentatus), which nested on the island of Mellum located at 53.43 deg N and 06.54 deg E, contained heptachlor at avg concns of 0.145 and 0.383 mg/kg(1) Gull-billed terns collected in Italy during 1982 and 1983 contained heptachlor at concns ranging from 0.01 to 0.70 ug/g with a geometric mean of 0.05 ug/g(2). Forster's tern eggs from Greenbay, WI contained heptachlor at concns ranging from 0.03 to 0.30 ug/g with a median concn of 0.09 ug/g(3). Forster's tern eggs from Lake Poygan, WI contained heptachlor at concns ranging from 0.01 to 0.03 ug/g with a median concn of 0.02 ug/g(3). Brain tissue of Goldeneye ducks that overwintered on the Niagara River contained heptachlor at concns ranging from 0.0023 to 0.0028 ug/g with a mean concn of 0.0026 ug/g in December 1984(4). In February to March 1985, brain tissue of the Goldeneye ducks that overwintered o the Niagara River contained heptachlor at concns ranging from 0.0025 to 0.0032 ug/g with a mean concn of 0.0028 ug/g(4). In years 1992-1993, the mean heptachlor concn in Squacco Heron nestlings and frogs colleted at Thermaikos Gulf (Greece) were 3.52 ug/kg dry wt (range, not detected to 6.12 ug/kg dry wt) and 1.46 ug/kg dry wt (range, not detected to 3.82 ug/kg dry wt), respectively(5). Tace amounts of heptachlor were detected in the plasma of juvenile alligators found in Woodruff, Apopka, and Orange lakes in Florida, detection limit = 0.25 ng/ml(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: HUMAN: Total heptachlor concns (ie, heptachlor and heptachlor epoxide) in human milk were measured at locations around the world as follows(1): Kenya (whole milk, 0.5 ug/l; 1979); Alberta, Canada (milk fat, 0.002 mg/kg; 1966-1970); Alberta, Canada (milk fat, 0.03 mg/kg; 1977-1978); Mexico (milk fat, 0.01 mg/kg ; 1976); Northeast, USA (milk fat, 0.07 +/- 0.04 mg/kg; 1975); Southeast, USA (milk fat, 0.13 +/- 0.21 mg/kg; 1975); Midwest, USA (milk fat, 0.09 +/- 0.07 mg/kg; 1975); Southwest, USA (milk fat, 0.07 +/- 0.10 mg/kg; 1975); Northwest, USA (milk fat, 0.07 +/- 0.10 mg/kg; 1975); Vienna, Austria (milk fat, 0.010-0.013 mg/kg; 1977-1978); France (milk fat, 0.06-1.30 mg/kg; 1971-1972); Germany (milk fat, 0.03-0.37 mg/kg; 1973-1974). Human milk samples obtained from 1,436 women residing in the United States were analyzed for chlorinated hydrocarbon insecticides. While heptachlor was recovered in less than 2% of the samples, heptachlor epoxide was found in 63% of the samples(2). The proportion of breast milk samples containing heptachlor epoxide varied significantly among the five geographic regions (66.1 to 128 ppb) with the southeastern states having the highest mean residual level(2). One possible explanation for the higher level in the southeastern states is that more homes were treated with heptachlor for termite control(2). The mean residual level of heptachlor epoxide for the whole United States was 91.4 ppb(2). A 5-month follow-up study of four pregnant Iraqi women without occupational exposure to organochlorine pesticides found an avg total heptachlor level in mother's whole milk of 0.051 mg/kg (range, 15 to 68 mg/kg)(3). Heptachlor was found at concns <1 to 2 ng/g in the milk of Australian women exposed to heptachlor from its use as an insecticide(4). The mean concn of heptachlor in human milk samples collected in Cairo (Egypt) in May 1987 was 1 ppb (1 of 31 samples)(5).

Reference: (1) Duggan RE et al; Pestic Res Levels in Foods in USA from July 1, 1969 to June 30, 1976 FDA and AOAC (1983)
(2) Martinez MP et al; Food Chem Toxicol 35: 621-24 (1997)
(3) Maitre MI et al; Sci Tot Environ 155: 105-8 (1994)
(4) Pico Y et al; J Agric Food Chem 43: 1610-15 (1995)

StringWithMarkup.String: COW: Heptachlor was detected with 0.2% frequency of occurrence and an avg concn of less than 0.1 ppb in 4,638 samples of cow's milk(1). The mean concn of heptachlor in 14.4% of 97 samples of pasteurized cow's milk from all parts of Spain was 0.011 ppm(2). Between Oct 1988 to Jun 1990, the mean concn of heptachlor and heptachlor epoxide residues in pasteurized cow's milk from Santa Fe City (Argentina) was 0.0549 mg/kg (range, not detected to 0.312; 99% of 120 samples)(3). Adapted infant formulas from Spain contained heptachlor residues of 13.5 ug/l (4 of 45 samples)(4).

StringWithMarkup.String: NIOSH (NOES Survey 1981-1983) has statistically estimated that 1,034 workers are potentially exposed to heptachlor in the US(1). The NOES Survey does not include farm workers(SRC). Occupational exposure to heptachlor may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where heptachlor is produced or used(SRC). In 1977, heptachlor was detected at levels ranging from 1.64 to 13.2 ppb in workplace air at a plant in TN that manufactured heptachlor(2). Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to heptachlor via inhalation of ambient air (especially indoor air of homes treated with heptachlor), ingestion of food (eg, fish) and drinking water, and products containing heptachlor(SRC). In a study of the exposure of applicators and residents to heptachlor when used for subterranean termite control in homes, results indicated that applicator exposure to heptachlor was 1.8 ug/kg per hr for dermal and 0.08 ug/kg per hr for respiratory exposure (total = 1.88 ug/kg per hr)(3); respiratory exposure of residents to heptachlor was 2.86 ug/cu m(3).

Literature references related to scientific contents from Springer Nature journals and books. These references have been ranked automatically by an algorithm which calculates the relevance for each substance in a Springer Nature document. It is based on: (1) the TF-IDF, adapted to chemical structures, (2) location information in the text (e.g. title, abstract, keywords), and (3) the document size.  Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

Chemical co-occurrences in literature highlight chemicals mentioned together in scientific articles. This may suggest that an important relationship exists between the two. Please note that this content is not human curated. It is generated by text-mining algorithms that can be fooled such that a co-occurrence may be happenstance or a casual mention. The lists are ordered by relevancy as indicated by count of publications and other statistics, with the most relevant mentions appearing at the top.

Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts.
